February 1, 1960
Warren F. Seibert
Senior Research Coordinator
Educational Media Branch
Department of Health, Education,
and Welfare
Washington 25, D* C.
Dear Warren:
Enclosing the proposals you sent and my summaries* Half of them are
here and the other half are coming in another envelope*
This was a frustrating job in many ways* First of all, as you know,
procedures are not clearly defined in most of the proposals, if they
are touched upon at all. Except for a very few, there were nothing
but vague references to the hypotheses to be tested* I am sure that
most of these problems were clarified in conference with the experi¬
menters before grants were made but this is not reflected in these
proposals - except for the illiteracy one. Most provide no infor¬
mation on sample size or, in a number of cases, on composition of
the sample* Anyway, I did the best I could to make them sound sen¬
sible* I thought that sending me the McLuhan proposal to abstract
was an especially low blow!!!
The only other problem that I had was in the classification scheme.
When the emphasis was on in-service training of teachers as they are
taaching in public schools (as a nuriber of these were), I put ML for
institutional level and TE for content level (e.g., as in proposals
269 and 253) where the course content was not indicated* When it
was, as in the language proposal, I put that. By the way, these will
look longer than they really are because they were typed on our large-
type electric typewriter. With standard type, they would take up
much less of the page*
I hope that you find these satisfactory. If not, please let me know.
Best,
Samuel L* Becker
Director, Division of
Television-Radio-Film
